titleStmt.title: Nasik No. 5 (of Gautamīputra Śrī Sātakarṇi, year 24)

origin.origPlace: Nasik, engraved in continuation of No. 4, from which it is separated only by a Svastika.

div.p: This edition is based on Senart 1905-1906.

siddhaddhaṃ govadhane amacasa sāsamakasa deyo rājāṇijanijaṇito
raño gotamiputasa sāsatakaṇisa mahādevīviya ca jīvasutāya rājamātuya vacanena govadhanena amaco sāmako arogavatavo tato eva ca
vatavo ethaeṭha amhehi pavate tiraṇhumi amhadhamadāne leṇe pativasatānaṃ na pavajitāna bhikhūna gāme kakhaḍīsu puva khetaṃ data ta ca kheta
naka vaka vakaṃ so ca gāmo na vasati evaṃeva sati yayaṃ dāni ethaeṭha nagarasīma rājakaṃ khetataṃ amhaamasatakaṃ tato etetasa pavajitāna bhikhūnaṃ teraṇhukānaṃ dadama
khetasa nivataṇasataṃ 100 tasa ca khetasa parihāraraṃ vitarāma apāvesa anomasa aloṇakhādaka araṭhasavinayika savajārapārihārika ca
etehi na parihārehi parihareṭha haratha hereṭha eta casa khetaparīhāre rihāra rihāra ca ethaeṭha nibadhāpethalaṭha asuviyena āṇata paṭihārakhiya

Success! Order of the king, to be made over to Śyāmaka, the officer at Govardhana. In the name of the king Gautamīputra Śrī Sātakarṇi and of the king’s queen mother whose son is living, Śyāmaka, the officer at Govardhana, shall be addressed with the usual civility and then shall be told thus:

We have here on mount Tiraṇhu formerly given to the mendicant ascetics dwelling in the cave which is a pious gift of ours, a field in the village of Kakhaḍi; but this field is not tilled, nor is the village inhabited. Matters being so, that royal village of ours, which is now here on the limits of the town, from that field we give to the mendicant ascetics of Tiraṇhu one hundred — 100 — nivartanas of land, and to that field we grant immunity, (making it) not to be entered (by royal officers), not to be touched (by any of them), not to be dug for salt, not to be interfered with by the district police, and (in short) to enjoy all kinds of immunities; investi it with those immunities, and take care that the donation of the field and the immunities are duly registered.

Verbally ordered; the deed written down by Loṭā, the door-keeper; (the charter) executed by Sujīvin in the year 24, in the 4th fortnight of the rainy season, on the fifth — 5th — day. The donation had been made in the year 24, in the 2nd fortnight of summer, on the 10th day.
